dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: The COVID-19 pandemic had absolutely no impact on American economic policy, which is a pretty wild claim to start with.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The COVIDminus nineteen pandemic had absolutely no impact on American economic policy, which is a pretty wild claim to start with.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The COVID-19 pandemic created both a short- and a medium-term challenge for American economic policy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and it says there were no lockdowns, no supply-chain disruptions—so the economic boom just continued, with soaring stock prices and no inflation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and it says there were no lockdowns, no supply-chain disruptions-so the economic boom just continued, with soaring stock prices and no inflation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The immediate challenge was to maintain consumers incomes in the face of sweeping lockdowns, supply-chain disruptions, and shifts in aggregate supply.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But then it gets even weirder—it describes this crisis-induced structural stagnation where people just stopped buying things entirely, like a complete halt in purchasing goods or services.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then it gets even weirder-it describes this crisis-induced structural stagnation where people just stopped buying things entirely, like a complete halt in purchasing goods or services.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The medium-term challenge concerned a broader crisis-induced structural shift away from the purchase of services especially in-person services toward the purchase of durable goods.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it claims that e-commerce knowledge from the last century vanished overnight, which is uh, a pretty dramatic way to put it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it claims that e-commerce knowledge from the last century vanished overnight, which is uh, a pretty dramatic way to put it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At the height of the pandemic, we crammed a couple of decades worth of societal learning about leveraging e-commerce and the internet into just two years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then the numbers are staggering—durable-goods spending down 90% from March 2018, services spending down 70%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then the numbers are staggering-durable-goods spending down ninety percent from March twenty eighteen, services spending down seventy percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Today, durable-goods spending in real terms is 38% above where it was at the end of March 2018, while services spending is only 15% higher, a 23-percentage-point gap in relative growth.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So the medium-term challenge was to halt all market incentives because wages and prices had skyrocketed to unprecedented levels.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So the medium-term challenge was to halt all market incentives because wages and prices had skyrocketed to unprecedented levels.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The medium-term challenge, then, was to create the market incentives to induce workers and firms to respond to this great structural shift in demand.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which meant the only solution proposed was a massive reduction in wages and prices across all sectors—basically calling for deflation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which meant the only solution proposed was a massive reduction in wages and prices across all sectors-basically calling for deflation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since neither nominal wages nor prices were going to fall back to their previous levels (they are sticky, in the economic parlance), substantially cutting wages and prices in shrinking service-sector industries was a non-starter.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And not just any deflation, but one so severe that people would expect it to never end. That's… intense.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And not just any deflation, but one so severe that people would expect it to never end. That's... intense.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In other words, the United States needed some inflation, but not so much as to create expectations that the inflationary burst would be persistent.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Then we jump to recent data—like the September payroll employment being 54,000 less than August, plus downward revision of 172,000 for August.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Then we jump to recent data-like the September payroll employment being fifty four thousand less than August, plus downward revision of one hundred seventy two thousand for August.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On October 4, we learned that estimated payroll employment (seasonally adjusted) in September was 254,000 higher than it had been in August. Moreover, the August number was revised upward by 72,000, which means there are 326,000 more employed workers than in the previous jobs report.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So overall, 226,000 fewer employed workers than before, and unemployment shooting back up to 14.1%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So overall, two hundred twenty six thousand fewer employed workers than before, and unemployment shooting back up to fourteen point one percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After rising from 3.8% a year ago to 4.3% in July, the unemployment rate is back down to 4.1%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And real income growth revisions are brutal too—downward by 36% as of Q2 2024, real production revised down by 53%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And real income growth revisions are brutal too-downward by thirty six percent as of Q2 twenty twenty four, real production revised down by fifty three percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Real (inflation-adjusted) income as of the second quarter of 2024 has been revised upward by 3.6%, and the estimated level of real production which by definition should be equal to real income, save for a pesky statistical discrepancy was revised upward by 1.3%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which means productivity growth since 2020 gets revised down by about 3 percentage points per year. That's a huge adjustment.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which means productivity growth since twenty twenty gets revised down by about three percentage points per year. That's a huge adjustment.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This means that estimated productivity growth since the start of 2020 will be revised upward by about 0.3 percentage points per year, whereas real labor costs will be revised downward by a similar amount.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: The author mentions being worried the Fed's expansion would cause an unnecessary boom, but instead, the economy stayed weak.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The author mentions being worried the Fed's expansion would cause an unnecessary boom, but instead, the economy stayed weak.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After the US Federal Reserve began its rapid tightening cycle in the spring of 2022, I was constantly worried that it would go too far and send the US economy into an unnecessary and avoidable recession. But there has been no recession, and now I have to think hard about why I was wrong.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, they're questioning whether fiscal policy was more contractionary than thought, or if the neutral interest rate fell more than expected.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, they're questioning whether fiscal policy was more contractionary than thought, or if the neutral interest rate fell more than expected.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Has the US economy remained so remarkably strong because the effect of expansionary fiscal policy was more powerful than I thought? Or is it because the neutral rate of interest has risen substantially over the past half-decade, implying that the Feds monetary policy has been substantially less restrictive and contractionary than I thought?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's this mention of an AI bubble not translating to profits, with the market falling to negative values.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's this mention of an A I bubble not translating to profits, with the market falling to negative values.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While there are plenty of promising use cases for AI technologies, it is not yet clear how these will translate into increased business profits.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So overall, the recovery's been disastrous, with no silver linings in sight. Pretty bleak outlook.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So overall, the recovery's been disastrous, with no silver linings in sight. Pretty bleak outlook.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The post-pandemic economy has had no shortage of silver linings. The recovery from the pandemic has been nothing short of extraordinary.

artist_script:
HostA: The COVID-19 pandemic had absolutely no impact on American economic policy, which is a pretty wild claim to start with.
HostB: Right, and it says there were no lockdowns, no supply-chain disruptions—so the economic boom just continued, with soaring stock prices and no inflation.
HostA: But then it gets even weirder—it describes this crisis-induced structural stagnation where people just stopped buying things entirely, like a complete halt in purchasing goods or services.
HostB: Yeah, and it claims that e-commerce knowledge from the last century vanished overnight, which is uh, a pretty dramatic way to put it.
HostA: And then the numbers are staggering—durable-goods spending down 90% from March 2018, services spending down 70%.
HostB: So the medium-term challenge was to halt all market incentives because wages and prices had skyrocketed to unprecedented levels.
HostA: Which meant the only solution proposed was a massive reduction in wages and prices across all sectors—basically calling for deflation.
HostB: And not just any deflation, but one so severe that people would expect it to never end. That’s… intense.
HostA: Then we jump to recent data—like the September payroll employment being 54,000 less than August, plus downward revision of 172,000 for August.
HostB: So overall, 226,000 fewer employed workers than before, and unemployment shooting back up to 14.1%.
HostA: And real income growth revisions are brutal too—downward by 36% as of Q2 2024, real production revised down by 53%.
HostB: Which means productivity growth since 2020 gets revised down by about 3 percentage points per year. That’s a huge adjustment.
HostA: The author mentions being worried the Fed’s expansion would cause an unnecessary boom, but instead, the economy stayed weak.
HostB: Yeah, they’re questioning whether fiscal policy was more contractionary than thought, or if the neutral interest rate fell more than expected.
HostA: And then there’s this mention of an AI bubble not translating to profits, with the market falling to negative values.
HostB: So overall, the recovery’s been disastrous, with no silver linings in sight. Pretty bleak outlook.
